hook.text: Your workflow ran 50,000 times last month. How many failed? How many produced low-quality results? How much did it cost? Without monitoring, you're flying blind.

buildup.text: Monitor: success/failure rates per step, end-to-end latency, cost per run, AI quality metrics (classification accuracy, generation quality scores), and queue depths.

discovery.text: Dashboard it: a single view showing total runs, success rate, average latency, cost trend, and recent errors. Review daily. This is how you catch degradation before users do.

twist.text: AI quality monitoring is harder than traditional monitoring: a workflow can 'succeed' (no errors, status 200) while producing terrible results. You need quality metrics, not just health metrics.

climax.text: Combine health monitoring (did it run?) with quality monitoring (did it produce good results?). Sample 1% of outputs for automated quality scoring. Alert on both health and quality degradation.

punchline.text: A workflow that runs without errors but produces garbage is worse than one that fails loudly. Monitor quality, not just health.

quiz.question: Why isn't traditional health monitoring sufficient for AI workflows?
options: A workflow can succeed technically (no errors) while producing low-quality AI outputs
Health monitoring already includes quality metrics
